Detailed Description

This class is responsible for dispatching events.

These include timers, network activity and file activity events.

void Mercury::EventDispatcher::attach ( EventDispatcher &  childDispatcher  ) 

This method attaches a child dispatcher to this dispatcher.

INLINE void Mercury::EventDispatcher::breakProcessing ( bool  breakState = true  ) 

This method breaks out of 'processContinuously' at the next opportunity.

Any messages in bundles that are being processed or timers that have expired will still get called. Note: if this is called from another thread it will NOT interrupt a select call if one is in progress, so processContinuously will not return. Try sending the process a (handled) signal if this is your intention.

bool Mercury::EventDispatcher::cancelFrequentTask ( FrequentTask *  pTask  ) 

This method removes a FrequentTask.

ErrorReporter& Mercury::EventDispatcher::errorReporter (  )  [inline]

uint64 Mercury::EventDispatcher::getSpareTime (  )  const

This method returns the amount of time (in timestamps) that the event dispatcher has been idle.

Currently the only activity it does in its spare time is 'select'. This can be used as a high-response measure of unused processor time.

INLINE void Mercury::EventDispatcher::maxWait ( double  seconds  ) 

This method sets maximum number of seconds to wait in select.

INLINE double Mercury::EventDispatcher::maxWait (  )  const

This method returns maximum number of seconds to wait in select.

This method processes events continuously until interrupted by a call to breakProcessing.

int Mercury::EventDispatcher::processOnce ( bool  shouldIdle = false  )

void Mercury::EventDispatcher::processUntilBreak (  ) 

This method call processContinuously until breakProcessing is called.

double Mercury::EventDispatcher::proportionalSpareTime (  )  const

This method returns the amount of spare time in the last statistics period.

This should only be used for monitoring statistics, as it may be up to a whole period (currently 1s) out of date, and does not assure the same accuracy that the methods above do.

WatcherPtr Mercury::EventDispatcher::pWatcher (  )  [static]

This method returns the generic watcher for EventDispatcher.

bool Mercury::EventDispatcher::registerFileDescriptor ( int  fd,
InputNotificationHandler *  handler 
)

This method registers a file descriptor with the event dispatcher.

The handler is called every time input is detected on that file descriptor. Unlike timers, these handlers are only called if you use processContinuously

Parameters:
fd The file descriptor to register
handler The handler to receive notification messages.
Returns:
true if descriptor could be registered

bool Mercury::EventDispatcher::registerWriteFileDescriptor ( int  fd,
InputNotificationHandler *  handler 
)

This method registers a file descriptor with the event dispatcher.

The handler is called every time a write event is detected on that file descriptor. Unlike timers, these handlers are only called if you use processContinuously.

Parameters:
fd The file descriptor to register
handler The handler to receive notification messages.
Returns:
true if descriptor could be registered

uint64 Mercury::EventDispatcher::timerDeliveryTime ( TimerHandle  handle  )  const

This method returns the time that the given timer handle will be delivered, in timestamps.

uint64 & Mercury::EventDispatcher::timerIntervalTime ( TimerHandle  handle  ) 

This method returns the time between deliveries of the given timer handle.

The value returned may be modified.

uint64 Mercury::EventDispatcher::timerIntervalTime ( TimerHandle  handle  )  const

This method returns the time between deliveries of the given timer handle.
